Sub-Competency: Patient Care 1: Emergency Stabilization
Level 1: Detects when a patient’s vital signs are abnormal; assesses ABCs and performs basic interventions
Level 2: Identifies a patient who is unstable and requires immediate intervention; addresses unstable vital signs and initiates advanced resuscitation
Level 3: Identifies occult presentations at risk for instability; reassesses after interventions
Level 4: Ascertains futility of interventions; integrates hospital support services in management
Level 5: Manages rare/complex presentations requiring stabilization

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 2: Performance of a Focused History and Physical Exam
Level 1: Elicits/communicates reliable comprehensive history and physical
Level 2: Focused history/PE that addresses chief complaint & urgent issues
Level 3: Prioritizes essential components in limited/dynamic circumstances
Level 4: Uses all potential sources of data for beneficial management
Level 5: Models effective use of H&P to minimize diagnostic testing

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 3: Diagnostic Studies
Level 1: Determines need for diagnostic studies; understands testing principles
Level 2: Selects appropriate studies, reviews risks/benefits; interprets results (EKG, imaging, POCUS)
Level 3: Prioritizes essential studies in limited/dynamic situations; orders with pre-test probability in mind
Level 4: Practices cost-effective ordering; considers post-test probability
Level 5: Proposes alternatives when barriers exist; discriminates subtle/conflicting results

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 4: Diagnosis
Level 1: Constructs list of potential diagnoses from chief complaint/initial assessment
Level 2: Provides prioritized differential
Level 3: Provides diagnosis for common conditions; modifies with clinical course/data
Level 4: Provides diagnosis for multiple comorbidities/uncommon conditions; recognizes reasoning errors
Level 5: Serves as role model/educator in deriving diagnoses & recognizing errors

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 5: Pharmacotherapy
Level 1: Describes drug classifications; asks about allergies
Level 2: Selects appropriate therapeutic agent; evaluates for adverse effects/interactions
Level 3: Considers array of therapy based on mechanism/intended effect; recognizes common adverse effects
Level 4: Selects agents considering patient preferences, allergies, cost, policy, guidelines; recognizes uncommon adverse effects
Level 5: Participates in departmental/institutional policy on pharmacy/therapeutics

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 6: Reassessment and Disposition
Level 1: Describes resources, basic patient education; identifies need for re-eval
Level 2: Makes disposition for routine conditions needing minimal resources; educates on simple discharge/admission; monitors interventions
Level 3: Makes dispo for routine conditions with resource utilization; educates on diagnosis, plan, meds, follow-up; identifies need for ongoing ED evaluation
Level 4: Makes dispo for complex conditions; educates on complex plans/transfers; evaluates changes in clinical status
Level 5: Participates in institutional committees/protocol development to enhance safe dispo

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 7: Multitasking (Task Switching)
Level 1: Manages single patient amidst distractions
Level 2: Task-switches between patients of similar acuity
Level 3: Task-switches efficiently to manage multiple patients of varying acuity/work-up stage
Level 4: Task-switches efficiently to manage the ED
Level 5: Task-switches efficiently under surge/high volume

Sub-Competency: Patient Care 8: General Approach to Procedures
Level 1: Identifies indications and anatomy/physiology; performs basic procedures (suturing, splinting)
Level 2: Assesses indications, risks/benefits, obtains consent in low–moderate risk; performs/interprets basic procedures with assistance; recognizes common complications
Level 3: Assesses risks/benefits in high-risk situations; performs/interprets advanced procedures with guidance; manages common complications
Level 4: Mitigates modifiable risk factors; independently performs/interprets advanced procedures; manages uncommon complications
Level 5: Teaches advanced procedures; independently performs rare, time-sensitive procedures; participates in peer review

Sub-Competency: Medical Knowledge 1: Scientific Knowledge
Level 1: Demonstrates scientific knowledge of common presentations and conditions
Level 2: Demonstrates scientific knowledge of complex presentations and conditions
Level 3: Integrates knowledge of comorbid conditions for complex presentations
Level 4: Integrates knowledge of uncommon/atypical/complex comorbid conditions
Level 5: Pursues and integrates new and emerging knowledge

Sub-Competency: Medical Knowledge 2: Treatment and Clinical Reasoning
Level 1: Knowledge of treatment for common conditions; identifies reasoning errors with substantial guidance
Level 2: Knowledge of treatment for complex conditions; identifies reasoning errors
Level 3: Knowledge of impact of patient factors; retrospectively identifies cognitive errors
Level 4: Comprehensive knowledge of varying presentations and treatments; re-appraises reasoning prospectively
Level 5: Contributes to body of knowledge on disease patterns/treatments; coaches others to avoid cognitive errors

Sub-Competency: Systems-Based Practice 1: Patient Safety
Level 1: Knowledge of common patient safety events; knowledge of reporting
Level 2: Identifies system factors; reports safety events through institutional systems
Level 3: Participates in analysis of events; participates in disclosure to patients/families
Level 4: Conducts analysis and offers prevention strategies; discloses to patients/families
Level 5: Engages teams/processes to modify systems; role models/mentors in disclosure

Sub-Competency: Systems-Based Practice 2: Quality Improvement
Level 1: Knowledge of QI methodologies/metrics
Level 2: Describes local QI initiatives
Level 3: Participates in local QI initiatives
Level 4: Demonstrates skills in developing/implementing/analyzing a QI project
Level 5: Creates, implements, assesses QI initiatives at institutional/community level

Sub-Competency: Systems-Based Practice 3: System Navigation for Patient-Centered Care
Level 1: Knowledge of care coordination, transitions of care, and population/community needs
Level 2: Coordinates care in routine situations; enables safe transitions; identifies local population needs
Level 3: Coordinates care in complex situations; enables complex transitions; uses local resources
Level 4: Role models coordination of care; advocates for transitions; adapts practice to population needs
Level 5: Analyzes/improves care coordination; leads innovations; advocates for populations/communities

Sub-Competency: Systems-Based Practice 4: Physician Role in Health Care Systems
Level 1: Identifies components of health care system; describes payment systems
Level 2: Describes interrelationships of system components; delivers care with consideration of payment models; identifies practice knowledge domains
Level 3: Discusses practice impact on broader system; engages patients in shared decision making; integrates IT for practice
Level 4: Manages system components; advocates for patient needs within payment models; describes core administrative knowledge
Level 5: Leads systems change; participates in health policy advocacy; analyzes practice patterns and requirements

Sub-Competency: Practice-Based Learning and Improvement 1: Evidence-Based and Informed Practice
Level 1: Demonstrates how to access/use evidence
Level 2: Articulates clinical questions
Level 3: Locates/applies best evidence, integrates with patient preferences
Level 4: Critically appraises/applies evidence in uncertainty/conflicting contexts
Level 5: Coaches others in appraisal/application; develops guidelines

Sub-Competency: Practice-Based Learning and Improvement 2: Reflective Practice and Commitment to Personal Growth
Level 1: Open to performance data
Level 2: Uses performance data to develop goals; identifies performance gaps
Level 3: Seeks/accepts performance data; analyzes contributing factors
Level 4: Continually improves goals using data; institutes behavioral changes
Level 5: Role models personal/professional goal development; coaches others in reflective practice

Sub-Competency: Professionalism 1: Professional Behavior and Ethical Principles
Level 1: Professional behavior in routine situations; knowledge of ethics principles
Level 2: Identifies triggers; takes responsibility for lapses; analyzes straightforward ethical situations
Level 3: Professional behavior in complex/stressful situations; analyzes complex situations; seeks help
Level 4: Prevents lapses in self/others; uses resources to resolve dilemmas
Level 5: Coaches others; addresses system-level ethical factors

Sub-Competency: Professionalism 2: Accountability/Conscientiousness
Level 1: Performs tasks with attention to detail; responds promptly
Level 2: Performs tasks timely with detail; takes responsibility for failures
Level 3: Performs in complex/stressful situations; recognizes factors affecting own performance
Level 4: Recognizes factors affecting others’ performance; ensures needs of patients/teams/systems met
Level 5: Takes ownership of system outcomes

Sub-Competency: Professionalism 3: Self-Awareness and Well-Being
Level 1: Recognizes personal/professional well-being status (with assistance)
Level 2: Independently recognizes well-being status; engages in help-seeking
Level 3: Proposes plan to optimize well-being (with assistance)
Level 4: Independently develops plan to optimize well-being
Level 5: Coaches others when emotional responses/skills do not meet expectations

Sub-Competency: Interpersonal and Communication Skills 1: Patient and Family Centered Communication
Level 1: Uses respectful language/behavior; identifies common communication barriers
Level 2: Establishes therapeutic relationship in straightforward encounters; identifies complex barriers
Level 3: Establishes therapeutic relationship in challenging encounters; reflects on biases; delivers information with guidance
Level 4: Easily establishes relationships regardless of complexity; independently uses shared decision making
Level 5: Mentors others in therapeutic relationships, reflection, and shared decision making

Sub-Competency: Interpersonal and Communication Skills 2: Interprofessional and Team Communication
Level 1: Respectfully requests consultation; uses respectful language; receives feedback
Level 2: Clearly requests consultation/resources; communicates effectively with team; solicits feedback
Level 3: Integrates recommendations from team; engages in active listening; communicates concerns/feedback to peers/learners
Level 4: Role models flexible communication; leads/manages teams; communicates feedback/criticism to superiors
Level 5: Role models leadership communication; facilitates team feedback in complex situations

Sub-Competency: Interpersonal and Communication Skills 3: Communication within Health Care Systems
Level 1: Documents accurately; safeguards patient info; communicates via institutional channels
Level 2: Organized reasoning in patient record; respectfully communicates system concerns
Level 3: Concisely reports reasoning; offers suggestions to improve system
Level 4: Clear/contemporaneous written communication; initiates difficult system conversations
Level 5: Models feedback for others’ communication; facilitates dialogue with broader stakeholders
